word.entryDescription: a place where you can buy tickets and catch a bus
word.entryExample: The bus station is in the centre of the city.

word.entryDescription: one of a number of places along a bus route where the bus stops
word.entryExample: There's a bus stop in front of my house.

word.entryDescription: a plant smaller than a tree with lots of thin branches
word.entryExample: The majority of the island is covered with short trees and bushes.

word.entryDescription: small areas of hair growing thickly on your forehead just above your eyes
word.entryExample: He is a man with bushy eyebrows.

word.entryDescription: a man who works in business
word.entryExample: Businessmen usually wear suits to work.

word.entryDescription: a woman who works in business
word.entryExample: She would like to be a businesswoman.

word.entryDescription: when you are busy, you have a lot of things to do
word.entryExample: Mum is busy in the kitchen.

word.entryDescription: used to link ideas together that are different from each other
word.entryExample: I like your dog but he's very noisy.

word.entryDescription: a solid yellow food made from milk which can be spread on bread
word.entryExample: Would you prefer your bread with or without butter?

word.entryDescription: an insect with large, often colourful wings
word.entryExample: Did you see that butterfly flying over the river?

word.entryDescription: a small round object which you put through a hole to fasten clothes
word.entryExample: Buttons have gone out of fashion.

word.entryDescription: a small part on a machine or device which you press; or a small area on a computer screen which you click on, in order to make something happen
word.entryExample: If she pushes the button by the cupboard, the air conditioning starts immediately.

word.entryDescription: to get something by paying money
word.entryExample: We can buy some vegetables in the market.

word.entryDescription: to travel on a bike
word.entryExample: Kim goes to school by bike.

word.entryDescription: by a large road vehicle which holds many passengers
word.entryExample: We go by bus to the town centre.

word.entryDescription: to travel in a car
word.entryExample: Lucy goes home by car.

word.entryDescription: a substance produced during the process of making or destroying something else
word.entryExample: By-products of the rainforest are cocoa, spices and rubber.

word.entryDescription: an informal word you say to someone when you are leaving a place
word.entryExample: Bye, see you tomorrow!

word.entryDescription: a restaurant (often found in factories, colleges, hospitals, etc.) where you choose and pay for your meal at a counter and then take it to a table
word.entryExample: The school cafeteria has two main courses every day.

word.entryDescription: a small restaurant which normally serves coffee and light meals
word.entryExample: I often have breakfast in the café.

word.entryDescription: a container for an animal made of bars or wire
word.entryExample: The rabbit is sleeping in his cage.

word.entryDescription: a sweet food made from flour, eggs, fat and sugar especially to celebrate somebody's birthday
word.entryExample: I'd like a chocolate birthday cake.

word.entryDescription: a business specialising in producing and/or selling cakes
word.entryExample: You can get a cake decorated with the design you want at the cake shop.

word.entryDescription: a young cow
word.entryExample: The calf stayed next to its mother.

word.entryDescription: to try and speak to someone by telephone
word.entryExample: Call me at 6 o'clock.

word.entryDescription: to phone someone who has called you previously
word.entryExample: It says I need to call back later when they are less busy.

word.entryDescription: relaxed or not anxious
word.entryExample: People who do yoga feel calm and creative.

word.entryDescription: a unit of energy provided by food
word.entryExample: If you're hungry, eat more fruit and vegetables – they're high in fibre but low in calories.

word.entryDescription: a large animal with a long neck and one or two raised parts on its back; lives in the desert
word.entryExample: Have you ever ridden a camel?

word.entryDescription: a thing you use for taking photographs
word.entryExample: I'm taking some photos with my new camera.

word.entryDescription: to put up a tent and stay for a short time
word.entryExample: It was dark and cold, so we decided to make a fire and camp in the cave.

word.entryDescription: a plan of activities with a specific aim in the areas of politics or business
word.entryExample: He started a campaign called 'Feed me Better'.

word.entryDescription: a leader of or a participant in a campaign
word.entryExample: Campaigners don't want the government to further develop the southeast.

word.entryDescription: a large vehicle for people to live and sleep in when they are travelling
word.entryExample: Campervans are a popular way to save money on accommodation.

word.entryDescription: the activity of staying in a tent on holiday
word.entryExample: I don't like camping because I'm scared of spiders.

word.entryDescription: a big area where people can camp
word.entryExample: Showers, toilets, and a shop are all important facilities in a good campsite.

word.entryDescription: a very large North American country between the US and the Arctic Ocean
word.entryExample: Canada is a very big country.

word.entryDescription: somebody who is being considered for a particular position
word.entryExample: There were 200 candidates for one post.

word.entryDescription: clever, careful, skilled and showing good judgement, especially in business or politics
word.entryExample: He turned out to be more canny than she'd thought.

word.entryDescription: the leaves and branches of trees, that create a kind of cover in a forest
word.entryExample: The top level of the rainforest is the canopy.

word.entryDescription: a place (in a factory, school, etc) where food and drinks are served, usually quite cheaply
word.entryExample: Emma went to the canteen to buy her lunch.

word.entryDescription: a hat usually with a small flat part at the front
word.entryExample: Baseball caps are very fashionable these days.

word.entryDescription: the part of a space vehicle which people travel in
word.entryExample: The Thunderbird capsule will carry private astronauts into space.

word.entryDescription: a vehicle with an engine and four wheels which carries people on roads
word.entryExample: My mum drives a car to work.

word.entryDescription: a crash involving a car
word.entryExample: Harry's dad had a car accident.

word.entryDescription: a place where lots of cars can be parked
word.entryExample: You mustn't park on the road, but you can use the car park.

word.entryDescription: a kind of vehicle without an engine which you pull behind a car and live in when you are on holiday
word.entryExample: The white caravan is very old.

word.entryDescription: a substance present in foods such as sugar, potatoes, flour, etc, which provides the body with energy
word.entryExample: Rice is full of carbohydrate.

word.entryDescription: a thin piece of cardboard usually with a picture on it; a short form of the word 'postcard'
word.entryExample: Can you send me a card when you are on holiday?

word.entryDescription: any type of exercises that make the heart stronger and healthier and which you do to keep fit
word.entryExample: Cardio exercises keep your heart and lungs healthy.
